node.title: Sarah Baartman endured horrific injustices in her life. Centuries on, they have not been forgotten
node.description: Not even an early death could end the abuse she endured. Marc Fennell talks to those who say her legacy can never be forgotten, for ABC RN's podcast, Stuff the British Stole.
node.content:
["Not even her early death could put an end to the abuse she endured in life.\u00a0It took a President's lobbying and the fight of her people\u00a0to finally lay her to rest.", "It's a Saturday night in London's\u00a0Piccadilly Circus.", "The year is 1810.", "An excited crowd gathers outside a theatre at the end of a laneway.", "Folks of all ages are dressed in their finest.", "They\u00a0pay two shillings and snake their way into a large room.", "On the\u00a0stage is a near-naked woman.", "A man standing close by orders her to sing, dance, walk.", "Those in the audience who've paid extra push to the front to poke the woman's black skin.", "A room full of English eyes stare at Sarah Baartman, the star of the show.", "The one they've lined up for.", "And Sarah Baartman stares right back.", "Born around 1789, Sarah, also known as\u00a0Sara or Saartjie, Baartman was a Khoisan woman, a First Nations person from the Western Cape of South Africa.", "\"We like to believe that we [Khoisan people] were the first human beings on earth,\" says\u00a0Paramount Chief Glen Taaibosch, chairperson of the Gauteng Khoi and San Council.", "Baartman \"definitely means a lot to us \u2026 we call her our Hottentot Queen,\" he says, reclaiming the offensive term for Khoisan people that was used in reference to Baartman when she was alive.", "She endured horrific injustices in her life and, centuries on, they've not been forgotten.", "\"We would just like to honour [her] and try and make up for what the colonialists did by taking her dignity, destroying a life like that; just to apologise that she was treated like that, ever, by other human beings,\" Chief\u00a0Taaibosch says.", "", "
An illustration of Sarah Baartman from the 1888 book, Le Costume Historique, by Albert Racinet.(Getty: Gamma-Rap)
", "When the Dutch colonised South Africa in the 1650s, Khoisan people like Baartman were \"essentially forced into Cape Town\" to find work and survive,\u00a0Natasha Gordon-Chipembere says.", "In the city, Baartman's body began to gain attention.", "\"She was short, not quite five feet, and she was very curvaceous. She had big hips and a big bum,\" says Dr Gordon-Chipembere, who is a professor of African diasporic literature and the author of Representation and Black Womanhood: The Legacy of Sarah Baartman.", "In Cape Town, Baartman worked as a maid at the home of the showman\u00a0Hendrik Cesars.\u00a0For some extra cash, Cesars began to show her at the city's hospital, where surgeon Alexander Dunlop was working. He too\u00a0saw\u00a0money-making potential in Baartman.", "", "
Graphic03Handbrake
", "Dunlop proposed a plan to Cesars.", "Travel to England and display Baartman as a sort of freak show attraction.", "The plan worked. Under the stage name \"the Hottentot Venus\", Baartman became a star.", "\"Come and see the Hottentot Venus for two shillings,\" the flyers shouted.", "Baartman was put in a tight costume designed to make her look naked.", "\"It was the mystery of her sex [and] sexuality, and its perceived perverseness, which drew people in to watch the show,\"\u00a0Dr\u00a0Gordon-Chipembere says.", "", "London audiences\u00a0were intrigued by the \"monstrosity\" of the performance.", "", "Baartman was marketed as\u00a0\"the missing link between man and beast\",\u00a0Dr\u00a0Gordon-Chipembere says.", "", "Audiences could\u00a0\"ogle\" the Black woman on stage.", "", "They could \"see \u2013 and feel \u2013 her round behind\", she says.", "The Baartman spectacle became so popular that it is thought to have inspired an early 19th century clothing trend: the bustle.", "It's a style of dress with padding at the back to create an artificial hump around the bottom.", "\"That whole fashion statement comes out of Baartman's presence,\"\u00a0Dr Gordon-Chipembere says.\u00a0", "\"Women were really anxious that their men were going to be lowered into wanting this sort of exotic, hyper-sexual African woman.\"", "So they tried to emulate her.", "", "
The bustle in\u00a0puffed dresses of the early 1800s accentuated\u00a0the bottom.(Getty: Hulton Archive)
", "Whether Baartman agreed to go to Europe, or was forced, is a contested point.", "Some argue it may have seemed the best option available to her at the time, pointing to a contract, which Baartman seemingly signed.", "Dr Gordon-Chipembere firmly disagrees.", "\"I don't believe that there was a negotiation and that Baartman signed anything or agreed to anything,\" she says.", "\"No.\u00a0It was like, tomorrow you're getting on the ship. We're packing you up \u2026 and you're off.\"", "", "
Dr Natasha Gordon-Chipembere says Baartman was forced to go to Europe.(Supplied)
", "", "
Paramount Chief Glen Taaibosch wants acknowledgement of the horrific treatment Baartman was subject\u00a0to.(Supplied)
", "Hendrik Cesars \u2013 at times referred to as Baartman's \"keeper\" and she, in turn, his \"property\" \u2013 directed Baartman's performances with a heavy hand.", "\"If she didn't want to be touched, [Cesars] would threaten to whip her,\" says Pamela Scully, professor of women's history and African studies\u00a0at Emory University, and\u00a0author of\u00a0Sara Baartman and the Hottentot Venus.", "\"She lived in all respects as someone who was engaged in urban slavery,\" she says.", "It didn't faze\u00a0audience members, who lapped up the show.", "Baartman had become one of the most famous celebrity exhibits of the 19th century.", "People lined up to poke and prod Baartman.", "\"More than one eyewitness says this is the thing that really seems to upset her,\" says historian\u00a0Sadiah Qureshi from the University of Birmingham.", "It's difficult for Dr Qureshi to read these accounts.", "\"They're really upsetting because \u2026 [Baartman] would have gone through that night after night after night,\" she says.", "And that's because now, in London, thousands of kilometres from her home, Baartman was stuck.", "\"She essentially is beholden to Hendrik Cesars once they're in England, because she has no ability to then survive in this new country,\" Dr Gordon-Chipembere says.", "She thinks Baartman would have felt \"incredible despair and loneliness, thinking about how far she was from home\".", "\"I think she would have been really shocked at the lack of humanity, the faces looking out at that stage, the violence,\" she says.", "", "
Dr Sadiah Qureshi describes distressing accounts of audience behaviour in Baartman's shows.(Supplied)
", "", "
Professor Pamela Scully says Baartman was engaged in 'urban slavery'.(Supplied)
", "Around 1814, Baartman and the Hottentot Venus show were taken to the stages of Paris.", "There, Baartman's living conditions became even worse.", "\"She [was] actually sold to an animal trainer,\" Professor Scully says.", "\"We think she probably was prostituted. I see her final years as pretty horrible.\"", "She was paraded at private gatherings and parties of the wealthy.", "Baartman was the \"surprise\" at the end of a night of drinking and an \"intriguing exhibit\" people could observe in private salons, Dr Gordon-Chipembere says.", "Her time in both London and Paris, she says, \"was obscene\".", "\"Europeans exhibited her, made money off her and ultimately betrayed her, as she was sold from owner to owner until her death.\"", "In December 1815, when Baartman was around 26 years of age, she died, \"penniless [and] probably of pneumonia\", Professor Scully says.", "In her short life, she had experienced incredible cruelty.", "\"It's inhumane. You don't treat another human being that way,\" Chief Taaibosch says.", "Shockingly, not even death would put an end to the violation of Baartman's body.", "Georges Cuvier, a French anatomist, dissected Baartman's corpse in an autopsy shortly after her death.", "\"But it was not an autopsy to find out why she died. It was an autopsy to look at her body, her bones, her genitalia,\" Professor Scully says.", "", "
An 1816 plaster cast of Baartman was repatriated from France along with her remains in 2002.\u00a0(Reuters:\u00a0Charles Platiau)
", "Cuvier was trying to prove the scientific supremacy of white men.", "\"There was this idea of the races of men,\" Professor Scully says.", "\"So you'd have white men, Indian, Asian, African, and then the Khoi and the San, [who were] very often seen as this kind of indeterminant group of people where science was not sure \u2013 were they, in fact, part of the animal kingdom? Or were they the lower rungs of humanity?\"", "Being a Black woman placed Baartman at the very lowest of those rungs.", "\"Europe was in a fury to codify and label everything in a Darwin-esque hierarchy, which of course had white men at the top,\"\u00a0Dr Gordon-Chipembere says.", "She says Baartman was viewed as an \"African savage\", a woman \"who was the link between the ape and the human\".", "Cuvier didn't just dissect Baartman; he actually preserved some of her remains \u2013 her brain, her genitalia and her skeleton.", "And he made a full body cast of Baartman. It and Baartman's skeleton were displayed in the Paris Musee de l'Homme, where they remained for 150 years, until being moved to a storage area in the 1970s.", "\"She quite literally [became] a museum object,\" Dr Qureshi says.", "When Nelson Mandela became South African President in 1994, he requested that Baartman be returned home.", "Finally, her remains were repatriated from France in 2002.", "Today Baartman rests in Hankey, a small South African town in the Eastern Cape.", "", "
Map of Europe and Africa
", "The fight to reclaim Baartman's body is over.", "But the fight to reclaim representations of Black women continues.", "Black girls' and women's bodies are still \"hyper-sexualised\" and considered\u00a0\"accessible\" today, Dr Gordon-Chipembere says.", "She draws a clear line from Baartman's story to modern representations of the Black woman.", "\"Whether we're looking [today] at domestic violence situations [or] police situations, we can go on and on about how Black women's bodies have not been cared for,\" Dr Gordon-Chipembere says.", "That includes in pop culture, where Dr Gordon-Chipembere says the way some Black women \"utilise their bodies\" harks back to \"a negative space with Sarah Baartman\".", "She argues that some contemporary popular figures, for example\u00a0rapper and singer Nicki Minaj, perpetuate that negative association and a \"particular hyper-sexualisation [that] started with Baartman's subjugation\".", "\"And no matter how empowered Black women in the 21st century feel about reclaiming their sexuality, it is still \u2026 a reaction [or] response to this violent permissiveness that was only applied to Black and Brown women's bodies via a colonist, patriarchal lens from the 17th century and beyond.\"", "", "
The coffin containing Baartman's remains arrives in Cape Town from France, on May 3, 2002.(Reuters)
", "", "
Dancers perform\u00a0at the burial ceremony for Baartman\u00a0in Hankey, South Africa.(Reuters)
", "", "
After his presidential election in 1994 Nelson Mandela began requesting the repatriation Baartman's remains.(Getty:\u00a0Per-Anders Pettersson)
", "", "
Khoisan leaders carry the coffin of Sarah\u00a0Baartman\u00a0to her burial place.(Reuters)
", "Dr Gordon-Chipembere says it's important to understand the historical context for how Black women's bodies are treated today.", "\"How did it get to the space where people can so readily feel like they can touch me or they can say things about my body or fat-shame me? Why does it seem like there's a permissiveness?", "\"Well, that permissiveness comes from some place. It just didn't happen yesterday. It has historical groundings that were incredibly violent,\" she says.", "\"And that is why we need to look at someone like Sarah Baartman.\"", "This story comes from ABC Radio National's Stuff the British Stole podcast. Season two was co-produced with CBC Podcasts.
